article:
'Nuclear transfer' is a form of cloning. The steps involve removing the DNA from
an oocyte (unfertilized egg), and injecting the nucleus which contains the DNA
to be cloned. In rare instances, the newly constructed cell will divide
normally, replicating the new DNA while remaining in a pluripotent state. If the
cloned cells are placed in the uterus of a female mammal, a cloned organism
develops to term in rare instances. This is how Dolly the Sheep and many other
species were cloned. Cows are commonly cloned to select those that have the best
milk production.

Despite this, the low efficiency of the technique has prompted some researchers,
notably Ian Wilmut, creator of Dolly the cloned sheep, to abandon it. Roger
Highfield [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/science/science-news/3314696/Dolly-creator-Prof-
Ian-Wilmut-shuns-cloning.html Dolly creator Prof Ian Wilmut shuns cloning]. The
Telegraph. 16 November 2007
